name: Tranylcypromine
summary: Tranylcypromine is a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI) used for the treatment of major depressive disorder.
description: Tranylcypromine, marketed under the brand name Parnate, is a non-selective, irreversible monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI) indicated for the treatment of major depressive disorder (MDD) in adults who have not responded adequately to other antidepressants. It works by inhibiting the enzyme monoamine oxidase, leading to increased levels of neurotransmitters such as serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine in the brain. Due to the risk of severe dietary and drug interactions, tranylcypromine is typically reserved for treatment-resistant depression and requires strict adherence to dietary restrictions to avoid hypertensive crises.

contraindications: Concurrent use with SSRIs, SNRIs, TCAs, bupropion, meperidine, or other MAOIs
monitoring_required: Signs of hypertensive crisis or serotonin syndrome

items: Treatment of major depressive disorder in adults unresponsive to other antidepressants

sections.text: Irreversibly inhibits monoamine oxidase A and B, preventing the breakdown of serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine, thereby increasing their levels in the brain.

adult.oral: Initial dose 10 mg twice daily; may increase by 10 mg/day increments every 1–3 weeks to a usual maximum of 30 mg twice daily (60 mg/day) as tolerated.

sections.text: Therapeutic effect may take 2–4 weeks; benefits persist with continued treatment.

other: Risk of hypertensive crisis with tyramine-containing foods (e.g., aged cheeses, cured meats, certain alcoholic beverages)
Risk of serotonin syndrome with serotonergic agents
Contraindicated with many medications—requires washout period before starting or stopping interacting drugs

items: Signs of hypertensive crisis (e.g., severe headache, chest pain, palpitations)

sections.pregnancy: Limited human data; use only if benefit outweighs potential risk
sections.lactation: Unknown if excreted in human milk; weigh risks and benefits
sections.geriatrics: Use with caution; monitor closely for orthostatic hypotension and drug interactions

sections.text: Gradually reduce dose over several days to a week to minimize withdrawal symptoms.

items: Reserved for patients with treatment-resistant depression due to dietary and drug interaction risks
Requires patient education on tyramine-restricted diet
Washout periods: at least 2 weeks before and after interacting drugs (5 weeks for fluoxetine)

seo.title: Tranylcypromine (Parnate) - Uses, Dosage, Side Effects, and Warnings
seo.description: Tranylcypromine (Parnate) is an MAOI antidepressant for treatment-resistant depression. Learn about dosing, side effects, interactions, and monitoring.
